{{Infobox musical artist | name = Hattie Hart | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = Hattie Bolten | birth_date = | death_date = | origin = [[Memphis, Tennessee]], [[United States]] | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Memphis blues]], [[country blues]] | occupation = [[Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1920s–1930s | label = [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor]], [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Hattie Hart''' was an [[United States|American]] [[Memphis blues]] singer and songwriter. She was active as a recording artist in the late 1920s to the mid 1930s, and her best known tracks were "I Let My Daddy Do That" and "Coldest Stuff in Town". Hart worked both as a solo artist, and previously as a singer with the [[Memphis Jug Band]]. Little is known of her life outside of music.{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p84800/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Joslyn Layne |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} It was stated that "Hart wrote gritty songs about love, sex, cocaine and voodoo". ==Career== Hart was born in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], [[United States]], around 1900, and first recorded with the Memphis Jug Band in 1928.{{cite book | first= Alan John | last= Britton | year= 2010 | title= Uncle Art | edition= 1st | publisher= AuthorHouse | location= Milton Keynes, England | isbn= 978-1-4520-8388-9 | page= 84}} She also had a reputation for the parties that she hosted at this time. Hart also sang in the [[Beale Street]] area of Memphis, [[street performance|busking]] with various musicians, where she became one of the best known performers.{{cite book | first= Jim | last= O'Neal | year= 2002 | title= The voice of the blues: classic interviews from Living Blues magazine | edition= 1st | publisher= Routledge | location= New York | isbn= 0-415-93653-5 | page= 53}} Hart was said to sing in the style of [[Sara Martin]],{{cite book | first= Samuel Barclay | last= Charters | year= 1977 | title= Sweet as the showers of rain | edition= 1st | publisher= Oak Publications | location= Michigan | isbn= 0-8256-0178-9 | page= 21}} and be a "marvellous, tough voiced singer".{{cite web |url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/77 |title=Big Road Blues Show |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Sundayblues.org |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Her earliest recording with the Memphis Jug Band, the self penned, "Won't You Be Kind?" (1928), contained blues dialect in the lyrics, ''"Now twenty-five cents a saucer, seventy-five cents a cup, But it's an extra dollar papa, if you mean to keep it up".''{{cite book | first= Stephen | last= Calt | year= 2009 | title= Barrelhouse words: a blues dialect dictionary | edition= 1st | publisher= University of Illinois Press | location= Urbana and Chicago | isbn= 978-0-252-07660-2 | page= 141}} There are five known recordings of Hart with the Jug Band between 1928 and 1930, before she undertook a recording session of her own in September 1934, with Allen Shaw and one other musician whom some blues historians believe to be [[Memphis Willie B.]] Hart recorded fourteen tracks, although only four of these were released at the time by [[Vocalion Records]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/nme-video/youtube/id/HfuNmuSVEck/search/hattie-hart |title=Hattie Hart: "I Let My Daddy Do That" |author= |date= |work= |publisher=NME.com |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Hart moved on to [[Chicago]], and it is believed she recorded there in 1938 under the name of Hattie Bolten. It is not reported whether this was her married name or a pseudonym.{{cite web |url=http://www.centrohd.com/biogra/h1/hattie_hart_b.htm |title=Hattie Hart |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Centrohd.com |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} After that, she disappeared from the public's attention and no further details of her life are known.{{cite web |url=http://www.memphishistory.org/Music/TheBlues/BluesArtists1/HattieHart/tabid/282/Default.aspx |title=Hattie Hart |author=Russell Johnson |date= |work= |publisher=Memphishistory.org |accessdate=October 16, 2011}} Hart's song, "I Let My Daddy Do That" was [[cover version|covered]] by [[Holly Golightly (singer)|Holly Golightly]] on her 1997 album, ''Painted On''.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r307916/review|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Painted On'' > Review )))}} ==Recordings== {{Expand list|date=October 2011}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
